candidates.title: Feat/eval similarity
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
- adds initial `evaluate_llm` functionality

## Overview

This PR introduces functionality for offline `llm` evaluations. Importantly, this PR enables the following:
- Users will now be able to execute an `evaluate_llm` function that takes a batch of `LLMEvalRecords`, user-defined `LLMEvalMetrics` that will be used to run an `LLM as a judge` workflow and an optional `EvaluationConfig`.
- The `EvaluationConfig` provides opt-in functionality for calculating embeddings from user-defined targets, computing similarity and performing clustering to identify unique clusters for metrics and computed metrics. 
- More information is in the documentation

candidates.title: feat(abi3-py39): add compatibility for multiple python versions
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
Simplifying the builds to use the `abi3-py39` pyo3 feature. This will allow us to build a single python wheel for py39+, which will use the stable C API.

This will build wheels for the following targets:

- `x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu` 
- `aarch-unknown-linux-gnu` 
- `aarch64-apple-darwin`
- `x86_64-apple-darwin`
-  `x86_64-pc-windows-msvc`

candidates.title: Fix/queue shutdown
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
This PR is updating the `ScouterQueue` to have better (hopefully) spawned task management. There is now a shared `TaskState` behind an `RWLock` for each Queue that is shared across the `ScouterQueue` and is used to manage each task. As part of this refactor, a cancellation token has been introduced based on recommended best practices from [tokio](https://tokio.rs/tokio/topics/shutdown). When shutdown is called, the cancellation token will be cancelled. This event is picked up by the `event_handler`, which then flushes the queue before exiting. For `Custom` and `Psi` profile types that use an additional `background_handler` for continual polling, an additional cancellation token is also provided.

candidates.body:
## Pull Request

## Add Versioning
- We currently support versioning of drift profiles, but the user must specify it manually.
- This pr introduces the same versioning as `Opsml`, but simplified a slight bit.
- Whenever a user creates a profile, the db will be checked if an existing version exists and will increment accordingly based on user input

candidates.title: Genai/metrics
candidates.body:
### Summary
Ok this is the big kahuna for introducing LLM metrics into Scouter.

What's new:
- Adding support for an `LLMDriftProfile`, which includes `LLMDriftConfig`, `LLMDriftAlertConfig` and `LLMetric`
- The `LLMMetric` is the primary method for creating a metric to attach to an LLM workflow. The idea being simple (hopefully). User creates an `LLMMetric` that includes a prompt and expected named parameters to be injected into the prompt. When a user creates a drift profile, `Scouter` will create a rust-serializable workflow that will then be saved with the profile. Whenever a user pushes an `LLMRecord` to the `ScouterQueue`, which pushes the record to the server, this record will be parsed and the context will be injected into the workflow, which will then run on the server and metrics will be extracted. The full implementation is written out in the docs
- Sql:
   - `llm_drift_record` table that stores the raw records containing context
   - `llm_drift` table that contains the metrics associated with a given llm metric workflow
   - Corresponding rust structs for inserting and getting records from these tables
   - Archiving logic for both tables
- Server:
   - Polling task that scans for `LLMRecords` and processes them according to the drift profile workflow
 - Client:
   - Added python stubs for new classes
   - Added new queue type for LLMs

candidates.title: stash for now
candidates.body: Many model drift detection techniques, such as Population Stability Index (PSI), Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence, and Chi-squared tests, rely on binning the distributions of input features. The way data is binned can have a big impact on how sensitive and reliable these metrics are. Instead of forcing a single method, we give data scientists the ability to choose the binning strategy that works best for their specific needs. Our library supports a range of binning methods, like quantile and equal-width, so users can run drift analysis that's better aligned with the shape and scale of their data.

candidates.title: 113/postgres refactor
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Summary
As defined in #113 - This finds a middleground where instead of doing single inserts into the server from consumers, we perform batch inserts. The downside to this approach is the need to  iterate over the records to build insert arrays for the postgres insert and unnest logic. However, we're leverage `itertools::multiunzip` to minimize iterations and extract all vecs

candidates.title: Fix/http runtime
candidates.body:
---
### Fix: ScouterQueue Startup Channel Receiver Race Condition on M1

**Issue:**  
On older M1 machines, the `ScouterQueue` startup channel receiver was closing before the background loop could send the startup notification. This resulted in unreliable queue initialization.

**Resolution:**  
- The background function is now spawned and executed during queue creation, ensuring the startup notification is sent reliably.
- The background task function now returns an error if the queue cannot be created, improving error handling.
- There is now a new `Event::Init` event that is used to determine if the loop has been initialized.

**Additional Improvements:**  
- Enhanced error messages to provide more context for easier debugging.

Related issue: #101
---

candidates.title: task manager
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Summary
In production, we're noticing memory creeps. This has not necessarily caused any OOM issues, but it suggests we may need to try a different memory allocator. This pr changes the allocator over to [mimalloc](https://docs.rs/mimalloc/latest/mimalloc/), which is a rust wrapper for microsofts [mimalloc](https://github.com/microsoft/mimalloc). This pr also adds a general `TaskManager` that is used to spawn tasks and manage the global join handle

candidates.title: Implement better psi threshold
candidates.body: We currently only support the industry standard rule of thumb/arbitrary threshold approach for detecting drift using PSI. This PR  allows us to dynamically calculate a more appropriate threshold. For additional information please see sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.2 of Yurdakul (2018) "[Statistical Properties of Population Stability Index](https://scholarworks.wmich.edu/dissertations/3208)"

candidates.title: Refactor/api integration
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
Focusing on simplicity for api integration:
1. Refactoring ScouterQueue to work as a local pub/sub service via channels in order to reduce blocking time
2. Channeling system allows us to move the tokio runtime to the ScouterQueue instead of having individual queues create and store their own runtimes (now they are just cloned from the parent runtime and passed down to the background tasks)
3. Simplify the creation of a ScouterQueue. Give developers a happy path. Now a user can load a queue directly from a local profile path.
4. Updated and refactored the docs website

candidates.title: Feature/long term storage #3
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
Summary:
- revamping how PostgresClient is implement:
  - Logic in `PostgresClient` has been broken out to various traits that are grouped based on use-case (e.g. psi, spc, user, archive, etc)
  - This will make the client easier to reason about and maintain
  - This also made is possible to turn `PostgresClient` into a staticmethod holder, which enables us to hold Pool<Postgres> on the scouter-server `AppState`, which simplifies things a bit
 - Adding in binned query splits for archived and non-archived data:
   - When a UI request is made for binned metrics, if a custom interval is provided the following logic will be executed:
   -  Custom interval will be split into archived and non-archived date ranges
   - If non-archived range exists, query binned data from postgres
   - If archived range exists, query binned data from parquet via datafusion
   - Join archived and non-archived data before returning
   
  Next pr will add storage integration for aws, gcp and azure

candidates.title: Feature/long term storage continued
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
Expand long-term storage logic to now include:
- a background data archive worker
- Logic to pull expired entities and associated data
- Write data to parquet
- Revise read parquet logic to read partitioned tables
- Testing
- Sql file organization

Parquet reading and writing takes advantage of time-base hive-partitioning in order to improve query performance when querying data from long-term storage. Standardized naming following `{space}/{name}/{version}/{record_type}`. When writing parquet, the following partitions are added (year, month day, hour). So a full path to a parquet file would look like the following:

`{space}/{name}/{version}/{record_type}/year={year}/month={month}/day={day}/hour={hour}`

The bin query is then used to select the appropriate partition, thus filter out parquet files that do no meet inclusion criteria based on specified timestamp

candidates.title: Feature add long term storage
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

This is the first of a few PRs that will add long-term storage of metrics via `datafusion` [link](https://datafusion.apache.org/).
Currently, postgres expires records every 30 days. This is done in order to maintain performance in scenarios of high volume. However, this opened up the quest about long-term storage of expired records and allowing for them to be queryable for the UI.  

This PR introduces initial logic for writing expired records to cloud storage via parquet and making them queryable. The following will be addressed in this and subsequent PR

1. Create initial logic for reading and writing server metrics to parquet
2. Logic that splits between querying metrics from short-term (postgres) and long-term (parquet) and joinging them when timestamps span both long-term and short-term
3. Server logic for background tasks that uploads records to parquet and partitions them based on timestamp, metric type, space, name and version (or some flavor of this for query performance)
4. Storage integration tests for gcs, s3 and azure

candidates.title: Breakout into separate crates
candidates.body:
## In progress

Separating into multiple crates to make everything easier to manage

## Overview:

This PR re-organizes scouter logic and layers in scouter-server logic, which allows us to have all client and server logic in one place.

### Crates:

`scouter-client` - crate that contains all rust entities used in `py-scouter`
`scouter-contracts` - contains shared contracts for server and client
`scouter-dispatch` - contains logic for handling dispatch logic for scouter alerts
`scouter-drift` - Core logic for calculating drift
`scouter-error` - Contains all Error types
`scouter-events` - Contains logic pertaining to event-driven consumers (kafka, rabbitmq)
`scouter-observability` - Logic for creating observability metrics
`scouter-profile` - Logic for creating data profiles
`scouter-server` - Axum server logic
`scouter-settings` - Shared config settings for Scouter
`scouter-sql` - Postgres logic for scouter
`scouter-types` - Shared types that are used throughout the Scouter crates

### Python
`py-scouter` - Python and client component for Scouter

candidates.title: Update deps
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Short Summary
Bumps deps for pyo3 and numpy along with a few others.

- Introduces new enum that is used by Psi and Spc Queues
- User will need to specify the feature type when passing to the queue. This will reduce the need to extract a python type into a rust type


New Queue insert structure:
- User will define a Features class that contains a list for features. Here the user will specify the type of feature (float, string, int)


```
Example:

Features(
    features=[
        Feature.float("feature_0", self.feature_0),
        Feature.float("feature_1", self.feature_1),
        Feature.float("feature_2", self.feature_2),
    ]
)
```

candidates.title: Add observer
candidates.body:
## Pull Request

### Summary

As part of the focus on monitoring and observability, we need to have base tools that can track api metrics and push them to scouter-server. This PR add both rust and python logic for tracking request metrics.

Adds:

- Adds rust `Observer` that create a mapping of requests, status codes, routes, and latencies
- Adds python `ScouterObserver` that runs a background thread that push request metrics to the `Observer` class. Every 30 seconds, the `Observer` collects metrics and push them out via `http`, `kafka` or `rabbitmq`
- Adds FastAPI integration that adds custom middleware to a fastapi apps where the middleware instantiates `ScouterObserver` and pushed metrics to it on each request.

### Short Summary

- Introduces new enum that is used by Psi and Spc Queues
- User will need to specify the feature type when passing to the queue. This will reduce the need to extract a python type into a rust type
